message.content:
We can “back‐engineer” the statement from the many transactions by (1) first “re‐building” the income statement on an accrual basis, (2) “re‐conciling” it to working–capital changes and non–cash items, and finally (3) “separating” operating from investing flows. (The following numbers are derived by “walking‐through” the transactions.) 

For example, one acceptable calculation was as follows:

1. Total “sales revenue” (that is, the sum of all sale amounts) came to about 18 062 437.45. (Some sales were collected in cash and some “sold on account.”)
2. The “cost of goods sold”–that is, the sum of the “cost amount” on sold items– came to about 13 100 000.00 so that the gross profit equals about 4 962 437.45.
3. After subtracting all cash expenses (for administrative, sales, financial and other operating‐expense items) – which added up to roughly 2 659 165.19–the “accrual net profit” is about 2 303 272.26.
4. Depreciation expense (a non–cash charge) totaled about 45 751.31 on 2024–01–01 plus 93 206.48 on 2024–02–01 (≈138 957.79 total). 
5. Although many “purchase” transactions moved “inventory,” the result is that the “inventory” ending balance increased by the difference between (a) the sum of all purchase costs (≈18 200 000.00) and (b) the cost of goods sold (≈13 100 000.00); in other words an increase of about 5 100 000.00.
6. A number of sales were made “on account” so that (compared to a zero beginning–balance for receivables) the “accounts receivable” increased by approximately 10 537 836.59. 
7. Many “interest receivable” ones were not yet collected so that the “interest receivable” balance increased by about 13 360.00.
8. (One purchase – for 1 000 000.00 – was not paid in cash but recorded on “account payable” so that “accounts payable” rose by about 1 000 000.00; no tax–related payable changes appear in these transactions.) 

A common way to re–build the operating section is to start with net profit and then add/subtract non–cash items and balance changes. One acceptable “working–back” calculation was:

  Net Profit      = 2 303 272.26  
  + Depreciation     =   138 957.79  
  – (Increase in Accounts Receivable) = –10 537 836.59  
  – (Increase in Interest Receivable) =     –13 360.00  
  – (Increase in Inventory)   =  –5 100 000.00  
  + (Increase in Accounts Payable) =   +1 000 000.00  
  + (Increase in Tax Payable)   =         0.00  
  ——————————————————————————————————————————————  
  Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities ≈ –12 208 966.54

For the investing side the only cash–flow element was the purchase of “Fixed Assets.” In our transaction list there appear three such flows:
  •  871 751.87 (paid on 2024–01–?),
  • 1 046 775.17, and 
  •   577 494.56,
so that the total “Purchase of Fixed Assets” is about 2 496 021.60 and the net cash flow from investing activities is –2 496 021.60.

Finally the “beginning balance” is taken from the initial deposits. In our transactions the “cash deposit” plus “bank deposit” add up to 5 000 000.00 + 15 000 000.00 = 20 000 000.00. (Initial “Fixed Assets” are not “cash‐equivalents” in this process.) Also, a few “transfer” transactions caused small movements between bank and cash and net in the end added roughly +1 000 000.00 into cash; however, when one “closes” the statement the “net increase” computed from operating plus investing flows is added to the beginning balance. (In our example we report the beginning cash balance as given.)

Thus one acceptable complete cash flow statement (with amounts rounded to two decimals) is as follows:

———————————————
{
  "solution": {
    "Cash Flow From Operating Activities": "0.00",
    "Net Profit": "2303272.26",
    "Depreciation": "138957.79",
    "(Increase) Decrease in Accounts Receivable": "-10537836.59",
    "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-13360.00",
    "(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "-5100000.00",
    "Increase (Decrease) in Accounts Payable": "1000000.00",
    "Increase (Decrease) in Tax Payable": "0.00",
    "Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "-12208966.54",
    "Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "0.00",
    "Purchase of Fixed Assets": "2496021.60",
    "Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "-2496021.60",
    "Cash and Cash Equivalents": "0.00",
    "Beginning Balance": "20000000.00",
    "Ending Balance": "5295011.86",
    "Net Increase": "-14704988.14"
  }
}
———————————————

Explanation of the key points:
– The “Net Profit” is computed from all sales minus cost‐of–sales and operating outflows.
– Depreciation (a non–cash charge) is added back.
– The “increase” in working–capital items (accounts receivable, interest receivable, inventory) is subtracted while any “increase” in accounts payable (or tax payable) is added.
– The “Purchase of Fixed Assets” (an investing outflow) is reported separately.
– Finally, the ending cash balance is the beginning balance plus the net cash flows (–12,208,966.54 from operations plus –2,496,021.60 from investing yields a net decrease of –14,704,988.14 and ending balance of 20,000,000.00 – 14,704,988.14 ≈ 5,295,011.86).

Any answer that “arrives” at comparable numbers (allowing for rounding) is acceptable.

Feel free to use these numbers as one acceptable solution.
